Award.AwardTitle: Routes to Sustainability for Natural Gas Development and Water and Air Resources in the Rocky Mountain Region

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1240584
Ryan

The current energy system in the United States relies on finite resources that are the major cause of climate change and a key source of global conflict. A sustainable energy system - one that uses renewable, low-carbon, affordable, and local energy sources - may be decades away. Natural gas is seen as the "bridge fuel" to a more sustainable energy system because natural gas combustion emits smaller amounts of greenhouse gases than coal combustion. However, conflicts have arisen between accelerated natural gas development and water and air resources protection. These conflicts are becoming acute in the Rocky Mountain region, which has always played an important role in the energy system of the United States. Most of the recent growth in natural gas production is the result of extracting gas from "unconventional" sources (coal-bed methane, shale gas, tight gas) with the techniques of horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing. Hydraulic fracturing requires large volumes of water that are chemically amended and injected to increase the permeability of the gas-bearing formations. The fracturing fluid left in ground and the fracturing fluid that returns to the surface (flowback), along with produced water, present risks to ground and surface waters. Natural gas extraction results in atmospheric emissions, particularly the release of greenhouse gases, oxides of nitrogen, and volatile organic compounds tied to the generation of ozone. These stresses on local water and air resources must be weighed against the benefits of natural gas production for the nation and the public must be provided with reliable information to make decisions about energy sources and resource protection. This Sustainability Research Network (SRN) addresses the conflict between natural gas extraction and water and air resources protection with the development of a social-ecological system framework with which to assess the conflict and to identify needs for scientific information. Scientific investigations will be conducted to assess and mitigate the problems. Outreach and education efforts will focus on citizen science, public involvement, and awareness of the science and policy issues.
The intellectual merit of this SRN proposal includes (1) examination of the effects of natural gas development on water and air resources by analyzing trade-offs between local, regional, and national costs and benefits in environmental, social, and economic domains (social-ecological systems); (2) review of industry practices for hydraulic fracturing, well drilling and casing, and gas collection infrastructure for best management practices recommendations (natural gas infrastructure); (3) investigation of the hydrologic processes that determine impacts of natural gas extraction on groundwater withdrawal and contaminant transport in drinking water aquifers and surface waters (water quantity); (4) characterization of the potential risks of fracturing fluid migrating to drinking water aquifers, the injection or discharge of flowback and produced water, and the mitigation of these risks by treatment of the flowback and produced waters (water quality); (5) improved spatial and temporal monitoring of air pollutants by a combination of high-resolution mobile sampling and the use of personal air monitors as an example of "citizen science" feeding data to air quality models that assess the local, regional, and national implications of natural gas development (air quality); and (6) quantitative and qualitative assessment of the health risks, both chemical and non-chemical, associated with water and air exposure.
The broader impact of this SRN includes improved public understanding of the effects of natural gas development on water and air resources and better decision-making regarding the local effects and regional and national benefits and costs of natural gas development. The broader impacts will be achieved through extensive education and outreach activities: (1) dissemination of best management practices in collaboration with all stakeholders, (2) diverse communication about scientists and scientific activity that will reach a broad portion of the public, (3) collaboration with Native American tribes and other under-represented groups disproportionately affected by natural gas development, (4) educational efforts aimed at providing appreciation for the science-policy interface at the university and K-12 levels, and (5) engagement of the public through citizen science, workshops, and scenario planning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The AirWaterGas Sustainability Research Network was formed to investigate the environmental, public health, political, and economic effects of oil and gas development in the Rocky Mountain region of the United States.  The major goals were to gather more information about these effects and to disseminate the results in a way that would improve policies and regulations involving oil and gas development.

The AirWaterGas network based at the University of Colorado Boulder was organized as teams examining these areas (Figure 1):

  • Social-Economic Systems
  • Water Use, Flow, Quality, and Treatment
  • Air Quality Monitoring and Forecasting
  • Health Effects
  • Practices and Regulations
  • Data Management
  • Education, Outreach, and Assessment

The Social-Economic Systems team at the University of Colorado Denver, Colorado State University, and the University of Colorado Boulder addressed social/politcal factors, economic factors, and decision analysis.  Major results included (1) assessment of the role of "policy actors" in guiding policy outcomes for oil and gas development (Figure 2), (2) incorporation costs and benefits of environmental conditions affecting real estate and air quality involving oil and gas development, and (3) creation of a decision support system that uses information gathered by AirWaterGas researchers to inform regulation of oil and gas development.

The Water Use, Flow, Quality, and Treatment team at Colorado State University, the University of Colorado Boulder, and the Colorado School of Mines addressed the effects of oil and gas development on water consumption and stress, risks of contamination of groundwater supplies, and treatment of oil and gas wastewater for re-use or safe disposal.  Major results included (1) an improved understanding of the fraction of water used by oil and gas development, (2) a framework for evaluating risks of hydraulic fracturing fluids, (3) an assessment of the effects of oil and gas development on well water quality in Colorado's Denver-Julesburg Basin (FIgure 3), and (3) a thorough evaluation of options and optimization of treatment techniques available for flowback and produced waters.

The Air Quality Monitoring and Forecasting team at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the University of Colorado Boulder examined emissions of oil and gas-related volatile compounds, developed low-cost air quality monitors, and forecast future air quality as a function of energy generation portfolios. Major results included (1) top-down and bottom-up monitoring and source attribution for five major oil and gas basins across the United States (Figure 4), (2) development, testing, and distribution of air quality monitors for industry, community, and educational uses, and (3) forecasts of the effects of continued use of fossil fuel energy on air quality for input to oil and gas regulations.

The Health Effects team at the Colorado School of Public Health examined the effects of proximity to oil and gas development on neurological, hematological, and developmental aspects of public health.  Major findings included (1) inhalation of organic contaminants from oil and gas facilities resulted in excessive cancer pre-natal development risks (Figure 5) and (2) residents near multi-well pads are exposed to air pollution, noise, and truck traffic at levels detrimental to public health.

The Practices and Regulations team at the University of Colorado Boulder faciitated the dissemination of AirWaterGas network research to the stakeholders, regulators, and the public.  They improved and maintained the Intermountain Oil and Gas Best Management Practices web site, created a database of state oil and gas regulations on the Law Atlas, organized workshops, seminars, and meetings with local, state, and national stakeholders.

The Data Management team at the University of Colorado Boulder organized the collection and availability of data for the AirWaterGas network.  Their databases contain over 51.1 million records covering (1) oil and gas well location, construction, and inspection information, (2) oil and gas spill and release reports, (3) baseline water well sampling reports, (4) real estate records, and (5) best management practice records.  These data supported research by teams across the network.

The Education, Outreach, and Assessment team at the University of Colorado Boulder worked with community groups and schools from K through 12 to increase awareness of oil and gas issues and AirWaterGas network research.  Their major efforts included (1) funding of community outreach projects incorporating AirWaterGas researchers, (2) development and delivery of low-cost air quality monitoring tools and curriculum to schools in counties with oil and gas development through the Air Quality InQuiry program (Figure 6), and (3) teacher workshops focused on development of curriculum addressing energy/environmental trade-offs.

More information about the AirWaterGas Sustainability Research Network is available at the network's web site, www.airwatergas.org.
